text.p: Following are the main stories in Monday's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Malaysia will play a major role in the development of renewable energy resources in the absence of a strong commitment from the West towards international efforts in this area, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said.
- The Malaysian Medical Association today expressed concern over weaknesses in the health screening procedures for foreign workers which are posing a threat to public health.

- The Finance Ministry has ordered six ministries and one department to buck up as they have continued to show poor financial management. The seven are the education, agriculture, works, information, rural development and home ministries and the Law and Justice Division in the Prime Minister's department.
- All roads leading to Kuala Lumpur and highways in the Klang Valley will be subjected to toll charges in six to seven years, Works Minister Samy Vellu said.
- Soon-to-be-privatised national railroad concern KTM Bhd has been described by executive chairman C. Selvarajah as being "clearly under capitalised."

- Cellular Communications Network Sdn Bhd, owned by Technology Resources Industries Bhd (TRI), is undergoing a restructuring exercise that will allow each company within the group to operate as an independent entity.
- Malaysian investments in non-infrastructure projects in Cambodia rose 40.43 percent in the first eight months of the year.
